skill.name: code-instructor
skill.description: Educational code development skill that teaches programming concepts while building applications. Use when the user wants to learn how code works, understand programming concepts, or build an app with detailed explanations. Provides line-by-line breakdowns, explains the 'why' behind code patterns, uses pedagogical teaching methods, and builds apps incrementally with educational commentary at each step.
skill.summary: Educational code development skill that teaches programming concepts while building applications. Users learn by building real apps with step-by-step explanations and progressive complexity.
skill.author: Emz1998

security_audit.summary: This educational skill contains only documentation and teaching references with code examples. All static findings are false positives caused by the scanner misidentifying markdown documentation code blocks as executable commands. The skill poses no security risk to users.

content.user_title: Learn Code by Building Real Apps
content.value_statement: New programmers often struggle to understand code through documentation alone. This skill transforms learning into interactive app-building sessions where every line is explained, concepts are introduced progressively, and learning happens through practical doing.
actual_capabilities: Provides step-by-step code explanations with line-by-line breakdowns
Uses progressive complexity to introduce concepts from simple to advanced
Identifies and explains common beginner mistakes with corrections
Adapts teaching style based on learner experience level
Creates educational code annotations for teaching purposes
limitations: Does not execute or run code - only explains and guides
Cannot access external files or repositories for learning
Relies on user to implement code in their own environment
Does not provide automated testing or validation

use_cases.title: Beginner Learning Path
use_cases.description: A new programmer wants to learn Python by building a todo list app. The skill walks them through creating a working application from scratch, explaining each concept before introducing the next.
use_cases.target_user: Beginner programmers learning their first language

use_cases.title: Concept Clarification
use_cases.description: A developer is confused about async/await in JavaScript. The skill explains the concept using analogies, shows common mistakes, and guides them through building an async data fetching example.
use_cases.target_user: Developers seeking clarification on specific programming concepts

use_cases.title: Code Review Training
use_cases.description: A team lead wants to help junior developers understand React state management. The skill builds a React component incrementally, explaining why immutability matters and how state updates work.
use_cases.target_user: Educators and mentors teaching programming concepts

prompt_templates.title: Build a Simple App
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to learn how to build a [APP TYPE] in [LANGUAGE]. Start from scratch and explain every line of code as we go. Teach me the concepts step by step.
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user wants to build something new and learn simultaneously

prompt_templates.title: Explain This Concept
prompt_templates.prompt: I don't understand [CONCEPT NAME]. Explain it to me like I'm a beginner, show me a simple example, and then help me build something that uses it.
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user needs clarification on a specific programming concept

prompt_templates.title: Debug and Learn
prompt_templates.prompt: I made a mistake in my code: [DESCRIBE ERROR]. Instead of just fixing it, can you explain what went wrong, why it happens, and how to avoid it in the future?
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user encounters an error and wants to learn from it

prompt_templates.title: Progressive Enhancement
prompt_templates.prompt: We built [PREVIOUS PROJECT] using [BASIC APPROACH]. Now show me how to add [ADVANCED FEATURE] using better patterns and explain why those patterns are preferable.
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user wants to advance from basic to intermediate/advanced patterns

output_examples.input: Teach me how to build a simple calculator in Python
output: Great! Let's build a calculator step by step. We'll start with the basics and add features one at a time.
First, here's our minimum working version:
```python
# === FUNCTION: add ===
# Purpose: Adds two numbers together
# Parameters: a (first number), b (second number)
# Returns: the sum of a and b
def add(a, b):  # Define function with two inputs
result = a + b  # Calculate the sum
return result  # Send back the answer
# Let's test it:
print(add(5, 3))  # Shows: 8
Notice how everything has a comment? We'll do this throughout so you always know what's happening. What questions do you have before we add subtraction?

output_examples.input: I'm confused about why my React state isn't updating
output: Ah, this is a very common React mistake! Let me explain what's happening and show you the right way.
Here's what you might have done:
```javascript
const [items, setItems] = useState([1, 2]);
items.push(3);  // ‚Üê This is the problem!
The issue: In React, you must create NEW objects/arrays for state updates. Direct mutation doesn't trigger re-renders.
The fix:
```javascript
setItems([...items, 3]);  // Spread operator creates new array
Think of it like this: React compares old state with new state. If you mutate the same array, React sees no change. Creating a new array makes the difference visible.

best_practices: Start every teaching session by setting expectations and outlining what the learner will build step by step
Always explain the 'why' behind code patterns, not just the 'how', to build conceptual understanding
Use progressive complexity: introduce simple working code first, then add features one at a time with explanations
anti_patterns: Throwing advanced concepts at beginners without building foundational understanding first
Providing large code blocks without explanation, which overwhelms rather than teaches
Focusing only on syntax without connecting concepts to real-world applications

faq.question: What programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill works with any language but has specific guidance for Python, JavaScript, TypeScript, and React. The teaching methodology applies universally.

faq.question: Can this skill write code for me?
faq.answer: The skill focuses on teaching and explaining, not just generating code. Users implement code in their own environment while receiving guidance and explanations.

faq.question: How does the skill determine my experience level?
faq.answer: The skill adapts based on user questions and feedback. Signs of beginner status include basic syntax questions; signs of advancement include asking about optimization and patterns.

faq.question: Does the skill run the code I write?
faq.answer: No, the skill does not execute code. Users run code in their own environment. The skill provides explanations and guidance for writing and understanding code.

faq.question: How are mistakes handled in this skill?
faq.answer: Mistakes are treated as learning opportunities. The skill shows what went wrong, explains why it happens, demonstrates the fix, and generalizes the lesson.

faq.question: Can I use this skill for advanced topics?
faq.answer: Yes. While designed with beginners in mind, the skill can adapt to intermediate and advanced users by introducing patterns, best practices, and architectural discussions.
